1: A period is a natural part of a person’s life when the body is preparing for pregnancy. If no pregnancy occurs, the lining of the uterus sheds. This is known as your period.
2: Periods start during puberty, when your body starts to change as an adult and has the ability to reproduce.
3: The first period occurs at around the age of 10-15 years old, but will vary with each individual.
4: Periods come every 26-35 days and last 3-7 days. The time between your periods and the length of your period can vary with each individual. Periods take time to regulate.
5: Common period symptoms include bloating, cravings, irritability, low energy, acne and cramps. You can manage these symptoms with sleep, hot compresses, movement and a healthy diet.
6: Period symptoms can change each month depending on your lifestyle, mental- emotional changes, stressors and physical activity.
7: Approximately 50-80ml of blood exits your body during a period, equaling to about 10-18 pads/tampons per cycle.
8: There are 4 phases in your cycle: menstruation, follicular phase, ovulation phase and luteal phase.
9: Canadians that menstruate spend an estimated $6,000 on menstrual products in their lifetime.
10: One third of Canadian menstruators, under the age of 25 struggle to afford menstrual products or can’t access them at all.
11: Another word for menstruation is “catamenia,” from the Greek word katamenia (kata = by + menia = month)
12: The word “period” first appeared on TV in a Tampax advertisement in 1985, starring Courteney Cox.
13: There is a board game that educates youth all about periods, called “The Period Game
14: Nearly 1 in 4 young people don’t know why people get periods or how to manage them.
15: 1 in 3 young people don’t feel prepared for their first period.
16: Approximately 11,000 disposable products are used in an average menstruator’s lifetime.
17: The average menstruator spends nearly 10 years menstruating in their lifetime.
18: A man named Dr. Earle Haas invented the first modern tampon in 1931, though variations of tampons were used thousands of years prior.
19: Disney made a movie about periods in the 1940s called, “The Story Of Menstruation.”
20: The documentary “Period. End of a Sentence” follows a group of Indian women fighting the stigma of menstruation and begin manufacturing pads. The documentary won an Academy Award in 2019.
21: An estimated 20 billion pads, tampons and applicators are sent to North American landfills annually.
22: Only 46% of Canadians feel comfortable talking about periods. Periods rank lower in comfortability to talk about than politics, sex, and Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs).
23: Your menstrual cycle and periods are controlled by hormones, like estrogen and progesterone.
24: 70% of menstruators have missed work, school or social activities because of their period.
25: The menstrual period occurs 14 days after ovulation.
26: Ovulation occurs halfway between your cycle when your hormones tell one of your ovaries to release a mature egg.
27: Since plastic can take as long as 500 years for pads & tampons to decompose, that means every disposable menstrual product that’s ever been used is still sitting in a landfill.
28: 63% of young people believe the government should do more to provide free period products to those who need them.
